fields.headline: Do do Dada
fields.bodyText: Tony Flynn's analogy of Blair-Brown to Lennon-McCartney (Letters, 2 September) on the ground that "neither produced as good songs on their own as they did together" is debatable, evidence, for example, Imagine and Yesterday. Lennon's imaginings and McCartney's yesterdays are surely worth believing in. The fact that Tony Blair goes on claiming to believe in his only further reveals what a wilfully Labour-party-and-human-race-betraying spin-merchant he continues to be. Michael Horovitz New Departures/Poetry Olympics, London • I am surprised that Tony Blair capitulated to a few hundred protesters (Blair cancels book party at Tate amid fears of protests, 9 September) when as prime minister, he ignored over a million. Sheila Woods Dunstable, Bedfordshire • We shouldn't lose sleep over a dropped "da da" from Bonanza (Letters, 8 September), but focus instead on the absence of Dada in our modern world. This creative movement was founded in 1915 to highlight the horrors and pointlessness of the first world war. Sadly, the movement lost its way during the 1920s. Would "A Journey" have chosen a different path, and how many thousands of lives would have been saved, had Dada still been alive in 2003? Peter McKinney Brentwood, Essex • I agree with Harriet Connides (Letters, 7 September), and have signed the petition, but surely the real point is that those of us who want a more civilised world must be petitioning to stop the execution of anyone regardless of their IQ. John Kemp Cheltenham • Further to Marilyn Davies's letter (9 September), I want to wish my father-in-law, Roy Clark, a good nominative deterministic outcome in the Feltwell ward of the QE hospital in Kings Lynn. Nic Groombridge Potters Bar, Hertfordshire • Following Patrick Barkham's article (Cambridge and me, G2, 9 September), can I pitch a piece entitled "The Polytechnic of North London (Essex Road branch) and Me – how it changed my life"? Steve Pinder London
